head.title: The Clothes of Africa In the Heart of Harlem

hedline.hl1: The Clothes of Africa In the Heart of Harlem

abstract.p: Gloria Lawyer opens Aziza's Enchanted Harlem, which sells African-style clothing made in Harlem, on 125th Street; logo (New Yorkers & Co column) (S)

block.p: Amid the influx of national chain stores like Disney's on 125th Street, a small shop, Aziza's Enchanted Harlem, opened in April to sell African-style clothing made in Harlem. There are colorful West African-style linen suits ($165) and silk, cotton or rayon scarves ($10 to $150). The store also offers imported household goods like glazed ceramic dish sets from Morocco ($10 to $70 apiece) and large hollow gourds from Mali that could be used to store small treasures ($150). The store, at 1 West 125th Street, shares space with an Islamic bookstore, Jihad A. S. Lateets.

''We're concerned that the business people of Harlem maintain some kind of presence,'' said the owner of the store, Gloria Lawyer, known as Aziza. ''Mickey Mouse and all that has come into the area, that's what's happening now.''
